description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Level of capacity of sub-national governments/administrations for planning delivery of basic services

Level of capacity of sub-national governments/administrations for monitoring delivery of basic services

Khan Younis Waste Water Treatment Plant (KY WWTP) is a strategic environmental project aims at protecting public health, water resources and environment of more than 320,000 residents of Khan Younis Governorate in the Gaza Strip.
populated place
Accountability - local government finance

1. Availability of additional fund required to implement and construct KY WWTP, Phase I. 2. The constructability review (design review), pre-contract and construction supervision services for KY WWTP being professionally provided by experienced international consultant to deliver the required outputs on time and to the appropriate quality. 3. Availability of functional waste water treatment plant of a capacity of 26,600 cubic meters per day to access 217,000 residents of Khan Younis to safe municipal waste water treatment services; 4. Availability of effluent and emergency pressure pipeline with a total length of 18.6 kilometers to discharge the treated waste water to the infiltration basins and to the sea outfall in emergency cases. 5. Availability of infiltration basin on 97 dunums area to annually recharge more than 9 million cubic meters of treated waste water into the aquifer to ultimately be used for agricultural purposes. 6. Availability of electrical power supply line required to operate the plant. 7. Level of engagement of local operators in implementing and operating waste water treatment plants.

comment.narrative: 1. The available fund from the Government of Japan is not sufficient to implement the comprehensive project of KY WWTP, Phase I 2. Limited local experience to provide constructability review (design review), pre-contract and construction supervision services for large scale treatment plants with complexity and sophisticated technology 3. Khan Younis has an absolute absence of functional waste water treatment plant. 4. Khan Younis waste water treatment plant will not be functional without effluent and emergency pressure pipeline 5. Around 5.2 million cubic meters of untreated waste water filtrated annually to aquifer via cesspits and around 4.3 million cubic meters discharged to the Mediterranean Sea in Khan Younis. 6. Khan Younis waste water treatment plant site has no power supply connection. 7. Not adequate experience of local operators to effectively implement and operate waste water treatment plants.

3. The Invitation to Bid for the Construction of Khan Younis WWTP and Buildings launched and the contract signed with the most responsive international bidder. 4. The Invitation to Bid for the Construction of the Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for Khan Younis WWTP launched and signed with the most responsive local bidders. 5. The Invitation to Bid for the Construction of the Infiltration Basins in Al Fukhari for Khan Younis WWTP launched.

3. The contract ITB-2016-158: Construction of Khan Younis WWTP and Buildings signed between UNDP/PAPP and the lowest priced international bidder, Metito (Overseas) LTD, at a total contract price of USD 18,935,575.73 on 14 December 2016.
4. The contract ITB 2016-219-UNDP: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP, Lot #2 Ductile Iron Pipe (UNDP package with around 5.6 kilometre length) signed between UNDP/PAPP and the lowest priced local bidder, Handala Company for Engineering Contracting & General Trade, at a total contract price of USD 1,757,992 on 14 December 2016.
The Invitation to Bid ITB 2016-219: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP, Lot #2 Ductile Iron Pipe (CMWU package with around 13.0 kilometre length) was launched in September 2016. UNDP and CMWU concluded the evaluation and the contract will be signed between CMWU and the lowest priced local bidder, Handala Company for Engineering Contracting & General Trade, at a total contract price of USD 3,821,020 in February 2017.
5. The Invitation to Bid ITB 2016-220-CMWU: Construction of the Infiltration Basins in Al Fukhari for KY WWTP (CMWU package) was launched in October 2016. UNDP and CMWU concluded the evaluation and the contract will be signed between CMWU and the lowest priced local bidder, Abu Shammala & Abu Dan Co. General Trade & Contracting LTD, at a total contract price of USD 5,636,000 in February 2017.

3. The work activities of the contract ITB-2016-158: Construction of Khan Younis WWTP and Buildings commenced on the ground and 50% of concrete works accomplished.
4. The work activities of the contracts ITB 2016-219-UNDP: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP (UNDP package) commenced on the ground and 20% of ductile iron pipes installed after inspecting and importing them from China and accessing them to Gaza.
The contract ITB 2016-219-CMWU: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP (CMWU package) signed between CMWU and the most responsive local bidder. The work activities commenced on the ground and 20% of ductile iron pipes installed after inspecting and importing them from China and accessing them to Gaza.
5. The contract ITB 2016-220-CMWU: Construction of the Infiltration Basins in Al Fukhari for KY WWTP (CMWU package) signed between CMWU and the most responsive local bidder. The work activities commenced on the ground and 30 % of excavation works accomplished.

3. The work activities of the contract ITB-2016-158: Construction of Khan Younis WWTP and Buildings commenced on 22 January 2017. The excavation works started on 13April 2017. Up to December 2017, more than 13,000m3 of concrete have been progressively casted for the different structures of the plant, representing more than 60% of the concrete works.
4. The work activities of the contracts ITB 2016-219-UNDP: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP (UNDP package) commenced on 22 January 2017. The inspection of the ductile iron factories in China was accomplished on 17 June 2017. The Israeli approval for accessing only 1,000 m of pipes to Gaza (out of 6,600 m) was issued on 28 November 2017. Risk of such partial approval is under assessment for the best way forward to manufacturing and accessing the approved pipes to move ahead with installation works.
The contract ITB 2016-219-CMWU: Construction of Main Pressure Lines to the Sea and to the Infiltration Basins for KY WWTP (CMWU package) was signed between CMWU and Handala Company on 8 February 2017. The work activities commenced on 23 February 2017. The inspection of the ductile iron factories in China was accomplished on 18 July 2017. The Israeli approval for accessing only 818 m of pipes to Gaza (out of 13,200 m) was issued on 18 October 2017. Risk of such partial approval is under assessment for the best way forward to manufacturing and accessing the approved pipes to move ahead with installation works.
5. The contract ITB 2016-220-CMWU: Construction of the Infiltration Basins in Al Fukhari for KY WWTP (CMWU package) was signed between CMWU and Abu Shammala & Abu Dan Company on 8 February 2017. The work activities commenced on 23 February 2017 and the excavation works started on 1 April 2017. description.narrative: (Modified 2016): 1. • # of Palestinians targeted by and benefited from CRDP interventions are able to endure hardship in Area C and East Jerusalem. 2. Area of land utilized, rehabilitated or restored to contribute to Palestinians’ less reliance on humanitarian support. 3.

comment.narrative: 1. According to OCHA’s Area C vulnerability profile (2014), a total of 297,900 Palestinians live in 532 residential areas in Area C. 67,016 Palestinians are living in communities and villages that are entirely in Area C. According to OCHA (2014), shelters in 69% of Area C communities are threatened with demolition and land in 50% of Area C witnesses land confiscation/requisition. As for East Jerusalem, the total number of population is 788,052 of which 283,873 are Palestinians making 36% (B’TSELEM, Background on East Jerusalem, 2012). Area suitable for reclamation in Area C is 182,300 dunums = 23% of total Area C: 810,000 dunums: 30% suitable for fruit trees, 22% suitable for forest, 48% suitable for range land. (UNDP/PAPP, Economic Analysis and Potential of Area C, 2011, internal document).

Original Outputs:
Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved. 1.1 1.1 20 units that would enhance quality of education to # of students in Area C and East Jerusalem improved (disaggregated by sex and age, serving minimum 50% female students)
Output 2: Improved access to and protection of natural resources. 2.1 Six water springs are rehabilitated ((with # of CM of water that become available) 2.2 170 water cisterns are rehabilitated (with # of CM of water that become available) 2.3 15 km of water network rehabilitated (with # of CM of water that become available) Output 3: Economic opportunities enhanced through support to livelihoods in Area C and EJRM 3.1 5000 dunums (30% of CRDP target) are reclaimed and become available for agricultural use. 3.2 60 km of roads are opened or rehabilitated.
4.1 Output 4: Rights of Palestinian citizens in Area C and EJRM are upheld through legal protection, advocacy and community participation and mobilization. 4.1 10 initiatives to promote human rights, advocacy and social cohesion are conducted. 4.2 At least 30% women and 50% youth (under 30) among those who participated in CRDP-supported initiatives that promote human rights, human-rights based advocacy community participation and mobilization Modified Outputs: Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved 1.1 Playgrounds and drinking facilities in four schools are rehabilitated. five kindergartens are rehabilitated to provide a safer and child friendly environment to # of preschoolers disaggregated by sex. 1.2 Two athletic fields for youth are provided/ rehabilitated and 3 women athletic spaces are provided (with # of beneficiaries. 1.3 200 students at least participated in activities that emphasize the Palestinian culture and traditions. 1.4 650 vulnerable and uninsured Jerusalemites have improved access to health services 1.5 Around 1000 Palestinians have improved their right to proper and decent housing in EJRM. In

Original Outputs:
Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved. 1.1 One play ground and one kindergarten were constructed. At least 60 Palestinian children have enjoyed pre-school education as a result of the construction of a kindergarten in Jiftlik in the Jordan Valley. In addition, at least 2,000 Palestinians from the age group 7-40 has enjoyed a safe playground in Fasayel in the Jordan Valley. Output 2: Improved access to and protection of natural resources. 2.1 At least 4,203 Palestinians in 2 Area C communities have benefited from rehabilitation of two water springs. Two water tanks were installed in Area B to increase the discharge of one of them.
2.2 A total of 10 water cisterns have been rehabilitated to benefit at least 1,000 Palestinians living in 2 Area C communities.
2.3 A total of 10 km of water network have been installed in four Area C communities to benefit at least 5,127 Palestinians. Output 3: Economic opportunities enhanced through support to livelihoods in Area C and EJRM 3.1 An Area of 203 dunums of land were reclaimed in 3 Area C communities benefiting around 4.462 Palestinians).
3.2 A length of 12.2 km of agricultural roads was rehabilitated benefiting at least 1,825 Palestinians and facilitating access to 1,100 dunums as a result. Output 4: Rights of Palestinian citizens in Area C and EJRM are upheld through legal protection, advocacy and community participation and mobilization. 4.1 Four community meetings were held with the participation of 200 Palestinians from 7 communities in Area C in which basic rights of these communities were discussed. Modified Outputs: Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved 1.1 Not fully achieved in 2016: Playgrounds and facilities in 4 schools in Tubas cluster are being rehabilitated. Completion is expected in mid-2017. In addition, Needs of 5 kindergartens in Qalqiliya cluster have been assessed. Bids were announced. Equipment’s delivery is under

Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved
1.1 45 units in 6 schools and six kindergartens in Area C are rehabilitated benefiting a # of students disaggregated by gender 1.2 Two athletic fields for youth are provided/ rehabilitated and three women athletic spaces are provided in Area C (with # of beneficiaries disaggregated by sex and age).
1.3 At least 5,000 Jerusalemite youth participated in activities to emphasize the Palestinian culture and identity (disaggregated by gender and age group).
1.4 Around 500 Palestinians have improved access to power in Area C and # of solar units provided by CRDP.
1.5 At least 400 vulnerable and uninsured Jerusalemites have improved access to health services.
1.6 Around 500 Palestinians have improved their right to proper and decent housing in East Jerusalem. Output 2: Improved access to sustainable livelihood and business opportunities
2.1 15 km of water network rehabilitated (with # of CM of water that become available).
2.2 80 dunums are reclaimed and become available for agricultural use.
2.3 30 km of agricultural roads are opened or rehabilitated in both clusters.
2.4 Two Local Economic Development (LED) units are established, one in each cluster and two forums are established.
2.5 32 new or existing business initiatives in the value chain are supported in Area C and East Jerusalem with at least 30% women participation.
2.6 115 new university graduates are placed for internship and 70% of them are permanently employed (dis-aggregated by sex).
Output 3: Strengthened governance including human capital knowledge management and public participation
3.1 # of members of 13 LGUs in Area C (disaggregated by sex) whose capacity has been increased.
3.2 Capacity of 15 CBOs and 13 LGUs in Area C at least is assessed and plans for improvement are in place.
Output 4: Supported nationally led developmental role in Area C and East Jerusalem
4.1 Around 10 knowledge and advocacy products and p

Output 1: Public and social infrastructure in Area C and EJRM improved
1.1 110 units in Area C and East Jerusalem are rehabilitated benefiting at least 6,147 students including 3,764 females. 1.2 Two athletic fields for youth were established in Area C for youth sport and cultural activities. These have already benefited 6,500 youth in both Tubas and Qalqiliya clusters including 800 females. In Qalqiliya cluster, three women athletic spaces were established and benefited 270 females.
1.3 A total of 18,146 Jerusalemite youth including 9,235 females participated in activities to emphasize the Palestinian culture and identity.
1.4 A total of 520 Bedouins has improved access to power through the installation of 52 solar units provided by CRDP.
1.5 A total of 823 vulnerable and uninsured Jerusalemites has improved access to health services through receiving subsidised treatment.
1.6 As a result of a mapping study for parcels of land in East Jerusalem, 5,564 housing units have been identified to be potentially constructed by Palestinians and expected to serve the same number of young families. In addition, three legal, engineering and social units were established in East Jerusalem. Moreover, 30 awareness workshops on legal, engineering, housing and social issues were conducted with participation of around 2750 Jerusalemites.
Output 2: Improved access to sustainable livelihood and business opportunities
2.1 A total of 21.3 km of water network was installed or rehabilitated in different communities in Area C and resulted in irrigating at least 2850 dunums of agricultural land. This activity has benefited at least 4,712 persons.
2.2 A total of 80 dunums were reclaimed and became available for agricultural use. At least 400 Palestinians benefited as a result.
2.3 A total of 28.3 km of agricultural roads were opened or rehabilitated in both clusters of Tuabs and Qalqiliya which allowed more than18,000 Palestinians to have access to at least 3600 dunums direct

comment.narrative:
1. Not Adequately: very weak fragmented system and absence of disaster risk management entity to streamline and coordinate disaster risk management activities (2013)
2. 0 (2013)

1. Largely: institutional and legal framework for DRM including coordination mechanism developed and consulted with stakeholders and endorsed by the government 2. 1: a proposed disaster risk management law drafted, consulted with stakeholders and submitted to the government for approval

1. Largely achieved: Institutional and legal framework for Disaster Risk Management developed, consulted with line ministries and civil society organizations in National workshop in May 2016 and approved by the Prime Minister's office.
2. (1) : Disaster risk management law was drafted, consulted with stakeholders and submitted to the Prime Minister's office for review

1. Largely achieved: working procedures for Palestine's Disaster Risk Management developed, consulted with the national technical team 2. (1) : the proposed Disaster risk management law reviewed and updated to reflect the latest changes in the DRM system, consulted with stakeholders and submitted to the Prime Minister's office for endorsement

1. Largely achieved: National Disaster Risk Management System including working procedures developed, consulted with the national technical team and approved. a Council of Ministerial Decree to establish a National Disaster Risk Management Centre, a National Platform and a National Technical Team issued on 14 March 2017 2. (1) : the proposed Disaster risk management law reviewed and updated to reflect the latest changes in the DRM system, and submitted to the Prime Minister's office for review. Endorsement of laws is a long process and requires intensive consultation with related stakeholders. it is anticipated that the law will be endorsed in the second half of 2018.

The project aims at anchoring national unity and social cohesion throughout the Palestinian society through support to consolidated governance mechanisms, social reconciliation, & enhanced civic engagement.
semi-independent political entity

comment.narrative: 1. Some 4,600 civil servants in the health and education sector hired pre-June 2007 (app. 30%) receive a salary but have not been reintegrated, while some 8,900 civil health and education personnel hired after June 2007 by the then de facto authority are attending work, but are not receiving a regular salary. 2. Absence of a coordination mechanism federating reconciliation initiatives. 3. Absence of a monitoring mechanism for implementation of reconciliation agreements; 4. Absence of a recovery strategy for the Gaza Strip.

1. Conference promoting Civil Society Networking planned for Gaza. 2. Local Economic Development (LED) Units Established 3. Led Specialist Hired. 4. 2009 Local Governance Diagnostic to be updated. 5. Synergized LED system to be developed. 6. GPC Strategy for Civil Servants to be drafted 7. Economic Mapping of five Gaza Municipalities

1. Conference held in Gaza with over 25 CSO's to discuss developing a network to advocate for reconciliation. 2. Five Local Economic Development Units in Rafah, Khan Younis, Nusseirat, Deir Balah, and Beit Lahia Municipalites of the Gaza Strip established. UNDP purchased necessary equipment and furniture to initiate the unit. 3. Five LED specialist recruited to work in the units. 4. A Local Governance Diagnostic report, the first since 2009, was drafted. 5. A draft Integrated National LED Framework was written and shared with the Ministry of Local Government. 6. A General Personnel Council (GPC) Civil Service Strategic plan for 2017 - 2022 drafted 7. Economic Mapping of Five Gaza Municipalities was initiated.

1. Economic Mapping to be completed of Five Gaza Municipalities. 2. Hold at least four events pertaining to Local Governance and Development (LED Framework, LED Conference, Local Diagnostic report, Economic mapping) 3. Conduct at least two activities fostering reconciliation with either Youth, Women, CSO's, and other marginalized groups.. 4. Hold at least one Public Administration related event. 5. Strategic Plan for Civil Servants is completed and launched. 6. Hold at Least 5 LED Forums.

The following results are attributed to UNDP. 1. Economic Mapping reports for five Gaza Municipalities are completed and approved by UNDP. Should be mentioned two reports for Area C and one for East Jerusalem were also approved. 2. Five events related local governance and development held, including a workshop presenting the local governance diagnostic report, the National Local Economic Development Conference, three economic mapping presentations to stakeholders including donors for the Area C reports, Gaza reports, and East Jerusalem.. 3. Two initiatives related to social cohesion/reconciliation and peace building took place. One was a conference by Civil Society Organizations of the West Bank and Gaza Strip meeting in Bethlehem to develop a plan of action focusing on strengthening social cohesion. The second initiative is the launching by youth of the Shugel Shabab campaign in the State of Palestine promoting peace building based on UNSCR 2250. 4. One Public Administration event was conducted in 2017, MENAPAR 5. Five LED forums held in the Gaza Strip.in Nusseirat, Beit Lahia, Rafah, Khan Younis, & Deir El Balah.

This project aims to protect the public health and improve the wellbeing of the Palestinian population in the Gaza Strip. This project will also contribute to more sustainable and integrated water management in the Gaza Strip through reuse of treated wastewater for irrigation purposes in Rafah Governorate. The quality of treated wastewater for irrigation schemes will be improved through efficient operation of Rafah wastewater treatment plant and Rafah post treatment facilities utilizing solar energy. Community awareness regarding the importance of wastewater reuse will be enhanced.
